messages.content: I feel so ashamed for messing up again.
It’s painful to feel ashamed—and it means you care. What would you say to a friend in your shoes? Let yourself hear that same kindness.
I can’t stop beating myself up for that mistake.
When self‑criticism shows up, try placing a hand over your heart and speaking gently: “I’m doing my best right now.” Notice how your body responds.
I’m exhausted from trying to be perfect.
Perfectionism is a heavy burden. What would it feel like to give yourself permission to be human—flaws, learning curves, and all?
I feel worthless when I don’t meet my own expectations.
Worth isn’t tied to performance. Take a moment to list three things you value about yourself that have nothing to do with achievement.
I keep replaying that harsh thing I said to myself.
Notice that inner voice—what tone does it use? Now imagine replying in a softer tone: “I accept myself even when I stumble.” Let that settle in.
I feel like I’m always falling short.
That’s a tough feeling. Let’s take a moment to reflect on three things you’ve done well recently, no matter how small.
I can’t stop thinking about how I messed up that conversation.
It’s easy to dwell on mistakes. Let’s practice self‑forgiveness: what would you say to someone else who felt the same way?
I feel like I’m not good enough.
That’s a heavy feeling. Let’s explore three things you appreciate about yourself that have nothing to do with achievement.
I keep worrying about what others think of me.
That worry can be consuming. Let’s practice self‑compassion: remind yourself that everyone has insecurities and it’s okay to be imperfect.
I feel like I’m always waiting for the other shoe to drop.
That anticipation can be exhausting. Let’s explore what you can do to create a sense of safety in your life right now.
